text: Morning in America.  Just look at it.  America in the midfifties, the suburban landscape stretching endlessly i the sun drenched distance.  White house upon white house. Emerald lawns, glistening with dew. In each driveway, a big Chevy, or a Ford, muscled with ch long tailfins that taper like the fins on rocket ships. Kids burst out of the houses, and zoom down sidewalks on trikes.  Mothers in bright dresses stand in doorways, watching.  The smiling mothers wave to one another, then back into their houses. Dogs bark, birds sing in trees of just the right height, boys and girls laugh and ring the bells on their trikes. is a delicious world, where dogs and birds and children a safe.

A family room with all the trappings of the era: a flagst fireplace, a console TV, a man's leatherette Barca-Lounge a pipe stand holding two pipes on a nearby table, boxes o children's games neatly stacked on a wall shelf.
A young mother, CAROL, her hair -in a pony-tail, stands a picture window in a corner of the family room, staring mi at the scene outside.

A little girl bounces a red ball on the sidewalk.  The ba gets away from her, and rolls into the street. At the same moment, a two-toned CHEVY, lush and huge, rou the corner. The girl sees the car coming, but still goes after the ba
Carol sees what is about to happen -- but she doesn't cry out, or bang on the window, or run for the front door.  S watches.  And smiles a little.
The girl careens gleefully into the middle of the street.

The driver -- a man in a loose fitting dark green suit, w shirt, thin brown tie -- sits behind the steering wheel o the car. Disturbingly, the man's hands are not on the steering whe Not only that, he is holding the morning newspaper up in front of him, reading, oblivious to the scene before him. Through the windshield, we see the little girl in the roa in front of him, going for her ball. CAROL Watches, her smile in place.
The little girl picks up her red ball, as the Chevy bears down on her.
An alarm suddenly CHIRPS.  The car automatically brakes t halt.  The man looks around the edge of his paper to see what is happening.
The car has stopped, inches from the girl. The girl giggles as, the man in the car gives her a big w She waves, then runs back to the sidewalk with her red ba
The man goes back to his newspaper, and the car, entirely its own, starts up again.  The car rounds a corner, and disappears.
Carol turns away from the window.  She startles when she sees her husband, JOHNNY, is there behind her.  He is in pajamas.  How long has he been there, watching her?
(gruff) Why'd you let me sleep so long?
It's Saturday, Johnny, you always -- (beat) Why are you staring at me like that?
He takes a step toward her.  He stands there, his thick b hair tousled with sleep, scratching his stubbled jaw, considering her.
I'm unhappy that you let me sleep so long.

He takes another step toward her.  She doesn't move a mus A little BOY suddenly enters the room.  Johnny turns, loo at his son, looks back over his shoulder at his wife.  Th without a word, he begins to walk out of the room.  On hi way out, Johnny's eyes flick to Carol's sewing basket, wh sits beside a sewing machine.  It is not the sewing that caught his attention, but a large pair of garment SCISSOR which lie across a fold of colored cloth.

Johnny stands on the front porch, scratching.  He walks d his front walk, and bends over to pick up the newspaper. Carol stands in the doorway, watching him. A SHADOW slides over Johnny, cast from above.  The air fi with the piercing WHINE of an engine.  Johnny looks up, alarmed. In the sky above him, just beyond the tips of the suburba trees, is a black PRECRIME POLICE HOVERCRAFT. The children, the mothers, Carol in the doorway -- everyo freezes in place, as Johnny is cast into an inexplicable drama. Racing SOUNDLESSLY down the street toward him, are SLEEK TECHNOLOGICAL MARVELS, lethal and efficient looking -- th seem to be cars -- but they are so different from the fat Fords and Chevies in the driveways that it is hard for us process them.

Helmeted police with mirrored visors erupt out of the car More police drop from the hovercraft in harnesses.  Their uniforms are black, seem actually to absorb light.  Their left hands are bare, their right hands are encased in som sort of complicated glove.

The glove is a weapon of some kind, the elongated index f ending in an open barrel. Clearly, this is not, as it first seemed, the past -- not America in the 1950's.  It is the neo-past, the retro wor of America 2040, where the familiar of yesterday is intermeshed with hypertechnology. And all of that hypertechnology is focused on JOHNNY, as makes a run for the house, sheets of newspaper scattering behind him.  He bursts up the front porch, shoving Carol of the way. Eight Precrime police officers assemble in the yard. From backpack, one of them quickly removes an instrument with handle grip and an ovoid screen.  It is a holographic sca He activates it, scans the OFFICER in front of him, and a IDENTICAL POLICE OFFICER takes three-dimensional form. The two real officers circle the house, repeating the man a dozen times. In less than a minute, a decoy force of men -- three dimensional, standing in place, but shifting and turning like living beings -- has been created.  An overwhelming police deterrent presence has been established.

The Precrime police overwhelm the interior of the house, too.  It is impossible to tell which officers are real, a which are scanned holographs.  The juxtaposition of the futuristic cops in a 1950's style house is disorienting.
Johnny, in his pajamas, crouches beneath a rack full of h wife's dresses.
Two OFFICERS, standing back-to-back, hold their gloved ha out in front of them, palm out.  When the first officer p his palm toward a door at the end of the hallway, his glo BEEPS softly.
The officer looks at his PALM.  A red thermal IMAGE appea on a small flexible screen -- the heat outline of a crouc man.  The first officer flicks his helmeted head to the s officer.
The room is packed with police -- how many are real?
Johnny squirms, his pajamas saturated with sweat.  He cal out through the door.
I didn't do anything!

Every OFFICER in the room lifts his gloved hand and point his index barrel at the closet door.  The effect is deepl accusatory. An OFFICER speaks, his VOICE electronically manipulated t be as menacing as possible.
Come out of the closet on your hands and knees.

Nothing happens.  Two officers aim their barrels at the perimeter of the door.  In repeated, small SONIC BLASTS, closet door is blown off of its frame, revealing Johnny a the dresses. Johnny starts to rise, and BAM, a section of floorboards blasted away beneath his feet.
Hands and knees!
Johnny trips among the splintered floorboards, and drops. He stays on his hands and knees, and approaches.  He lift his head and looks up at the officer.
I didn't...

Another OFFICER 2 bends down with a DEVICE -- the words "IdentiScan" on its side -- and blips a red laser light  into each of Johnny's, eyes, reading his irises.  The  officer nods affirmatively to the other officer.
POSITIVE FOR JOHN PALMER.

(to Johnny) John Palmer, if you were being arrested for any other crime, I would now read you your rights. (beat) But you are under arrest for the future murderer of your wife, Carol Palmer.  You have no rights.
Johnny, on his hands and knees, goes limp.

In the background, Johnny is guided into a Precrime polic vehicle as the neighbors look on.  Carol and her son stan in the doorway, stunned. TWO OFFICERS remove their helmets.  The first man is tall sandy-haired, good eyes, deeply blue; This is PAUL ANDERS late thirties, Director of the Precrime Division, Washing D.C. The second man is ED WITWER, Anderson's second in command late thirties, big like Anderson, good face, strong in th shoulders, short brown hair. The two men are deeply comfortable together.  They can sp or not.  It doesn't matter -- they still communicate.  Tw good cops, good together. They walk side-by-side around the house, dematerializing holographic decoy cops.
Thought we might a had a runner.
Anderson seems tired, takes a moment to answer.
Yeah, a runner.
A little chase -- that'd been good.
Fifty cops on the scene takes the chase out of them.
(smiles) But only eight of us were real.
Witwer dematerializes the last decoy.
We ever get a runner, I'd be too old to give chase.
You'd chase.  You'd love it,.  Man.
They get to the front of the house and watch the Precrime vehicle holding Johnny zoom SOUNDLESSLY away.
I love it more Johnny boy doesn't get to murder his wife.
(beat) It's a beautiful world.

The children play on their trikes.  The wives talk among themselves.  The birds sing, the dogs bark. The little girl bounces her red ball again.  She stops a. minute, when two pieces of newspaper blow past her, unexpectantly littering the orderly suburban landscape.

Decorated in a 1950's style.  Anderson lies in bed beside his wife, LISA, a pretty, green-eyed brunette.  It is ear morning, they are both awake.  Her hand caresses his ches Maybe they will make love. Lisa's hand stops suddenly on the center of Anderson's ch
Jesus, Paul.  Your heart's hammering. (playfully) I excite you that much?
He turns to her, and the grim set of his jaw makes her sm vanish.
I used to love being a cop.
You're still a cop.  I'm a factory worker.  We don't catch murderers. We process them.
Lisa takes a long breath.  She's been down this road befo She speaks reassuringly.
You're the best homicide cop in the country.
ANDERSON snorts disdainfully.
Great -- except there's no such thing as homicide.  What I do best doesn't exist anymore.
PAUL. (beat) You're the Director of a perfect system.  A Cop with a perfect record
The
Precogs have a perfect record. They identify the accused -- I just put on my monkey suit and go round them up.
Lisa hugs him, kisses the back of his neck.
And then
prosecute them.  And they go to jail.  And lives are saved. Thousands of lives. (beat) And that's a cop's dream.
Anderson is silent for a time.  He sighs, then smiles, an turns to his wife, takes her in his arms.
No.  You're a cop's dream.
Anderson steps out of the shower, and begins to towel him dry- He glances out a casement window.  He tilts his head curious, then wipes at the steam on the window.
Lisa stands in the backyard in her nightgown, talking on cell phone.  She hangs up, moves quickly back into the ho
Cocks his head, then goes back to toweling off.

Checkered linoleum floor.  Appliances out of the 1950's. Except there are little differences.  When Lisa puts a sk of eggs on the stove, the heating element is not an elect coil, or gas but a shimmering field of light. Lisa is dressed in a blue jersey skirt and a brief jacket Anderson wears a gray suit, thin blue tie, white shirt, wingtipped shoes.  He doesn't look up from the newspaper he speaks.
Who called?
Lisa keeps her back to him as she flips the eggs.  She to her long brown hair.
No one.  I called about my hair. Getting it done this afternoon.
Anderson looks like he's about to say something else, whe suddenly someone RAPS on the back screen door.  Anderson Lisa both turn and smile.
Come on in, neighbor.  Want some coffee?

FRANK D'IGNAZIO, 65, white-haired, robust, hesitates befo coming in.  A thin METALLIC ARM with a red laser light ar quickly down from above the doorway, shines into each of EYES, scanning the irises.  The arm lifts out of view, th screen door UNLATCHES. Frank enters the kitchen, carrying a basket of tomatoes.
Brought these for your supper.
Oh, Frank.  That's so sweet.  Thank you.
Sweet, nothing.  I gotta get rid of these things.  One plant, and I'm invaded by tomatoes.  When I was a kid ...
Anderson laughs, claps his friend and neighbor on the bac teases him.
Before all this genetically engineered crap ...
Frank gives him an ornery look, then a smile.
Yeah well, it's true.  It used to be a challenge to grow things.  An art. Now you put one plant in the ground -- then jump the hell out of the way.
Anderson gestures for Frank to sit down.
Coffee?
Nah, thanks.  Can't stay.  You guys are rushing off to work anyway.
Lisa sets the eggs down in front of Anderson.
You and Ellie come for supper then.
We'll barbecue.
Frank nods and pushes on the screen door.
You betcha.  We'll bring some more tomatoes -- a new batch will have grown by then.
They all laugh, Frank exits, Anderson goes back to his pa

Anderson waves to Lisa.  Her big Studebaker drives off do the tree-lined street and away. Anderson approaches his Chevy.  He doesn't take out a key unlock it.  There is no lock.  He slides in behind the wh Doesn't take out a key for the ignition -- there is no ignition. A thin METALLIC ARM arches down from the sun visor, scans Anderson's EYES, identifying him.  A seat harness wraps a him, and the car STARTS. Anderson picks up a folder marked "Precrime" and begins t read through the papers.  The Chevy backs out of the driv and takes him to work.

A vast spread of corporate and government buildings -- th spillover from Washington D.C. across the Potomac River i Virginia. Beyond the white of Washington is "The Sprawl" -- the mas unzoned city that has spread uncontrolled on the outskirt of the Capitol.  It is impenetrable and uninviting, espec to those comfortable in the utopian suburbs. Anderson's Chevy moves in a sea of fifties-type cars. Occasionally, an ultramodern vehicle zips past them.  In sky above is another sea -- of advertising dirigibles, holographic billboards, hovercrafts, skim-jet transports. On one of the holographic billboards giant words begin to flash: "I LIKE MIKE!"
Then a picture of the smiling President appears.  Then th words: "RE-ELECT PRESIDENT MIKE BILLINGS FOR ANOTHER FOUR

Through his windshield, Anderson glances at a holographic road sign. THE ROAD SIGN reads: "FBI Headquarters 1 mile.  CIA Headquarters 1.5 miles.  PRECRIME Headquarters 2 miles." Anderson goes back to his papers.

Anderson sits in a too large office in a too large chair. He abruptly rises and begins to pace.  The room is large, but he paces like a lion confined in a cage. He punches an intercom.  A female VOICE responds.
Yes, Director Anderson?
Where's Ennis Page?  Why hasn't he delivered this morning's Precog discs?
Ed Witwer opens the door to the office., and casually wal in.
I'll find him, sir.
Ed shakes his head, smiles.
Bullying the staff again, Director Anderson?
Screw you.
Anderson turns away and stares out a large window.  Witwe joins him.
Was that fun for you, yesterday?
The Johnny Palmer bust?
Yeah.
It was okay.  We got our man.
Anderson takes a long breath.
When do we

not get our man? They turn as Ennis PAGE, 44, a thin, tight little man wit burr cut hair, knocks and enters the room.  He carries a black BRIEFCASE marked: "Zone 218 - Washington/Alexandria, VA." The case is cuffe to his wrist.
Sorry I'm late, sir.  Precogs put out a heavy national volume this morning -- four for our zone.
(DISTRACTED) Put the case on my desk, Ennis.
Page hesitates, doesn't do it.  Anderson moves quickly to Page.
What was I thinking.

Anderson leans over the BRIEFCASE.  A small panel recedes red laser scanner clicks on, scans Anderson's eyes, BEEPS affirmatively, then clicks off.  The cuff on Page's wrist falls open. Now Page puts the case on Anderson's desk.  Page hesitate Anderson and Witwer know just what he's going to do.  Pag reaches down, unable to resist straightening a pile of pa strewn on Anderson's desk. Anderson and Witwer exchange knowing smiles.  When Page l up they try to cover, but are not quick enough.  He frown tightly, and heads for the door. Anderson calls after him.
Thanks, Ennis.
Witwer turns to leave, too.
Now that's a guy who

really cares. Witwer grins to himself as he walks out of the office. Anderson takes a deep breath and goes to his desk, and op the briefcase.  Four small bright DISCS sit in rows.  He removes one, places it in a VIDEO MONITOR that lifts into view from the center of his desk.  He sits back, weary, a watches.

A young black woman stands in a hallway.  She stares at a door, gun in hand.  She opens the door, enters a bedroom. She glides toward a bed, where a man lies sleeping.  She lifts the gun and fires it into his sleeping form. ANDERSON pops the disc, jots down some notes, pops in a n disc.
A white woman stands at a stove, cooking.  A man comes up behind her slowly, silently, a necktie taut between his h He raises the necktie toward her neck
He's not watching the screen.  He is out of his chair now looking out the window.

A tour of Precrime is in progress, like the public relati tours run by present-day FBI.  The TOUR GUIDE, a pretty, smartly uniformed woman in her twenties, leads a group of adults and children, all with glowing nametags, through t building.
Welcome to the main headquarters of Precrime.  Smaller Precrime branches are scattered throughout the United States.
The group follows the guide slowly through the lobby.
Precrime was established in 2030, with the harnessing of the remarkable talents of the Precognitive mutants.
She points cheerfully to a stubby little man, MR. HARRIS.
Mr. Harris, can you tell me how many Precogs there are?
Three.  Uh, right?
That's exactly right!  A lot of people assume there are Precogs in every branch office.
But there are only three Precogs, right here in this building.  And the information they give us, we send out to all the other branches. (beat) And what is that information -what do the Precogs do?
An eager boy, TIMMY has the answer to that one.
They protect us.
The guide tousles his hair.
(chipper voice) That's right, Timmy.  Because of the Precogs, you're going to grow up murderfree.  Isn't that something?
They ever wrong?  The Precogs ever screw up when they predict a murder?
The guide laughs tolerantly.

Never, sir.  It's an infallible system.  The Precogs predict a homicide, and our Precrime police then apprehend that future murderer before the event occurs.  And right next door is the Judicial Center, where we prosecute the future murderers.
Can we see the Precogs?
No, I'm sorry.  That part of the building is not open to the public. (beat) Now, if you'll just step this way ...
She waves the group on toward an elevator.
The chamber is an elaborate, hypertech hospital, construc for the maintenance of three beings -- the Precogs.  They are triplets -- two of the Precogs are male, one is femal

Technicians swarm all over them like worker bees.  The bo of the Precogs are being tended to: exercised, cleansed, groomed. The head of each Precog is encased in a complex, ornate H that seems to be an amalgam of organic tissues and bright metallics.  The helmets pulse slightly, and the surfaces seem to flow and shift, like oil on water. A network of micro-thin cables that are actually strands light, rise Medusa-like from each helmet, then centralize into a single strand, and connect to a massive mainframe computer. The Precogs appear to be in suspended animation, or in co They are absolutely still and limp -- except for their fa Their faces are in constant motion, the lips mouthing sce from murders only they can see.  Life for a Precog is an endless cycle of death.

we recognize her fragile and perfect FACE from the openin scene of the movie.  She floats in a glowing nutritive ba Like her brothers, she  seems to be eternally young, or eternally old. The technicians lift her from her bath.  She is dried, dr in a robe, then guided into an over-sized, throne like ch Her brothers are guided into their thrones, on either sid of her. Not once are their helmets removed.  What they feed into mainframe is too valuable.  It must be gathered twenty-fo unrelenting hours a day.

Ennis Page sits in a room just off the Precog Chamber.  H can see them through a large window.  He works a large computer console, the gathering point for the information the Precogs constantly feed the computer. Perhaps every ten seconds, a small DISC is released by th computer, and mechanically gathered, sorted, and placed - Page's watchful eye -- into a black case. ANDERSON is in the room standing quietly behind Page.  As Director, Anderson is authorized to come and go, but from his fussy movements, it's obvious Page sees anyone else i the room as an intruder in his special domain. Anderson turns and looks through the window at the Precog
What would they think about if we unhooked them?
Page looks up from his work.
They don't think, sir.  They just see.
Anderson is silent.
They're not even alive, really.
Anderson contemplates the scene, nods to Page's words, th turns and walks out of the room, as Page looks on.

The female Precog sits in her chair.  Her eyes are open. She faces the window that looks into Page's main frame ro In the window we see Anderson leaving the room. The female Precog's eyes drift closed.

A trial is in progress.  The defendant is Johnny Palmer. sits, ashen, at a table, his DEFENSE ATTORNEY beside him. There are no jurors in the Juror BOX.  There is a JUDGE, and stern.  There are a few people in the public seats. The Precrime prosecuting attorney is Lisa Anderson.  She wears a black robe, and addresses the Director of Precrim Anderson, who sits in the witness stand.
Director Anderson, do you swear that the disc you now present to the court is the only and authentic disc of the future murder of Carol Palmer by her husband, John Palmer?
It is a ritual that they both have acted out hundreds of times.  Anderson gives the rote answer as he holds up the DISC.
Yes.  This is the only and authentic disc of the event seen by the Precognitive mutants and recorded by the Precrime Division.  This is the immutable evidence of the infallible system.
The murder of Carol Palmer will occur ... ?
In one week -- June 16th, 2040 at 10:33 in the morning.

Lisa steps back.  The judge reaches out and Anderson hand him the disc.  The judge inserts it into a special video machine on his desk.  Anderson steps down, his ritual par in this trial completed. A huge MONITOR comes to life behind the judge.  He does n turn around to watch -- he has his own monitor. Johnny Palmer watches, eyes wide.  We now see, in detail, what we previously heard the Precogs act out in the begin of the movie.
The Palmer's family room.  Johnny reaches into Carol's se basket for the scissors.  Carol stands defenseless in fro of him.  Their son cowers in a corner of the room.
Johnny, please --
"Johnny, please.  Johnny please."
You're scaring me.
DADDY, DON'T.  DADDY
Johnny approaches his wife with deadly menace.
(considering) I don't like you any more, Carol.
(imploring) Put the scissors down.  You're scaring me. Please.
We cut away from the monitor and stay on JOHNNY PALMER'S as he sits at the defense table.  He winces at each terri
Oh, Carol.
Johnny!  Stop!
Don't grab at me!  Let go...
Daddy!  No!
Johnny Palmer cries out as the MONITOR goes blank.
I didn't do it.  I'm innocent!  It didn't happen!
The JUDGE hits his gavel.
How does the defense plead?
The defense attorney glances at his watch, then quickly rattles off the words to his part of this judicial ritual
The defense acknowledges the infallibility of the system.  We are Guilty.  We throw ourselves at the mercy of the court.
No! No! The Precogs are wrong!  No!
The court guards are on him in an instant.  They lead him out of the courtroom.

Anderson pushes down a tight hallway thick with police an enters a disheveled room.  The fifties interior is drab: Formica table, bad curtains, a frayed Lazy Boy positioned front of a TV. Ed Witwer is already on the scene.  He stands a few feet from the BODY of a man, gunshot wound to the head, a hand on the floor nearby.
(to Anderson) Looks like the old days.
Anderson nods to his former partner.  Anderson leans over the body.
That would be bad news for an infallible system.
Witwer is suddenly bored.
We know it can't be a murder -- the Precogs would've seen it.  Why do you insist on coming to these things?
Keeps the system honest.  And besides, I like to pretend I'm a cop.
Anderson turns to an officer.
Who's got the Coroner?
Another OFFICER steps forward with a large blue case.
Right here, sir.

The officer places the case beside the corpse, and opens latches.  Inside the case is a large metallic APPARATUS: "Coroner." It comes to auto-life, and begins to unfold itself - It r crab-like, and steps out of its case. Except for his mouth, the doctor doesn't move.  His proje image stands beside the body, his arms folded behind his back.  He is the interface, the way the humans communicat with the crab apparatus.
Hi DOC.
Hello, Director Anderson.

The coroner crab begins to walk the body, which is face d on the floor.  It moves slowly, hesitating as it crawls t body's back to insert various razor thin probes and core samplers through the shirt and into the spinal cord.
This a homicide, Doc?
I'm presently analyzing neurohormones, Assistant Director Witwer.  I have not concluded my examination.
The crab engulfs the back of the head, probes the wound.
I'm detecting carbonization of skull fragments around the entry wound.
Witwer whispers to Anderson.
Bingo.  The guy put the gun to his own head.
I have not determined that yet, Assistant Director.
Witwer grins.
You have good ears for a ghost, Doc.
The coroner crab steps away from the body.
Please rotate the corpse to the lateral supine position.

Two officers turn the body face-up.  The crab inches clos to probe the face.  Disconcertingly, it lifts the eyelids and examines the interior of the mouth, so that for a mom the manipulation makes the corpse seem alive. Then the crab moves down the trunk and the legs At last, comes to a standstill.  The holographic Doctor closes his eyes as if in thought.
Can you imagine if this
was a homicide?  Who even knows how to hunt down a killer any more?
Anderson gives him a hard look.
know how, dammit.   You know how.
Easy, partner. (beat) But you know what I'm saying.  The state legislatures are pushing to stop funding for training homicide detectives ...
God bless the Precogs.
The Doctor opens his eyes.
This event is a negative homicide. A mortal wound was generated by a .22 calibre bullet self-delivered to the parietal 'portion of the skull on June 10th, 2040, at 11:57 pm,
Eastern Standard Time.  This event is a positive suicide.

The holographic doctor begins to shimmer, then disappears back into the coroner crab.  The crab crawls back into it case, folds its probes and legs tight to its metal body, shuts down. Witwer turns to Anderson.
It's time to stop coming to these, partner.
Anderson watches as the med techs lift the body onto a stretcher.
Yeah.  You're right.
Anderson, in black-tie, with Lisa in a shimmering blue go at his side, moves through a huge room filled high level government officials and politicians.
A little bit of me dies every time I come to one of these things.
It's only a party, Paul.
I'd never have let them appoint me to Precrime if I'd have known this was going to be part of it.
You're exactly what Precrime needed. An amazing homicide cop and a real person in an unreal job.
Exactly.
The public loves the Precogs.  But they give people the creeps, too.  You're something they understandp a regular cop running things.
Anderson sighs as he looks around the elegantly appointed banquet hall.
Let's invite all these irregular assholes over for a barbecue.  Burgers and beer - think they'd come?
A barrel-chested man with a great shock of pepper gray ha SENATOR MALCOLM, 58, takes hold of Anderson's elbow from behind.
I'd come, Mr. Director.  And I'd make all the other assholes come with me.
Lisa reddens, Anderson gives an embarrassed cough.  The Senator laughs and claps him on the back.
Nice job this morning.  Another negative homicide.  The Precogs never let us down.
Mrs. Malcolm smoothly occupies Lisa, while the Senator ea Anderson in the opposite direction
I have a dream, Paul.
I know you do, Senator.
Hundreds of Precogs.  Not just predicting murders, but predicting
all crimes.  Burglary, arson, assaults ...
How about jaywalking?  Littering? Now
there's a crime. The Senator smiles through his teeth.
I don't want a police state, you know that.  But we have an opportunity here, and
No sir, we
don't have that opportunity.  There are only three Precogs.  They're a lucky accident of nature.  There are no more.
(beat) We can
make more.  Just give me your support.  Help me increase funding for the Precog Engineering Project.
Precogs aren't sheep or pigs.  Seeing into the future is a gift, a nonreproducible event.
There was only one Mozart, and there are only three Precogs.
Fuck Mozart.  The people want to be safe.  They want that more than they want food or love.
He gestures at the room full of glittering partygoers.
Look at us -it's 2040 and we've wrapped ourselves up in the 1950's like a big security blanket.  Why? Because we want to feel like they felt.  Safe.
Senator, a world filled with hundreds of Precogs is not my idea of a safe place.
The Senator gives it one last shot.
Sure could use your help, Paul.
I decline, Senator.  I'm sorry.
(icily) Don't think I'll come to your barbecue after all.
The senator moves off.  Anderson stands stiffly among the sea of black-ties and exquisite fifties dresses.

Anderson walks through the lab with a tall, pale man, DR, RESFIELD, 60, the head scientist.  It is not a place that warms Anderson's heart. Biotechnicians work at long stainless steel tables dissec and examining protoplasmic tissue masses.  Other technici peer through massive microscopes.  Still others use robot arms to manipulate radioactive organics behind leaded-gla barriers.
You don't get out here much.
Not my sort of place.
Dr. Resfield emits a dry little laugh.
The head of Precrime squeamish?
When it comes to needles and scalpels, yeah.
I promise we won't use any on you.
What
do you use them on?
(beat) On bits of this and that.

Anderson looks at him.  The doctor pauses outside a thick door.  An IdentiScan device quickly reads their eyes, and the door opens with an electronic hiss. Anderson looks around the lab.  Technicians lower mesh cylinders into some sort of chemical VAT.  Another techni turns a dial, and an electric charge courses through the roiling liquid.
What's happening here?
We're in an interesting phase.
What's in the cylinders?
Neurotissue.
From ...?
A fusion of sources.  From the Precogs' deceased mother.  From the Precogs themselves.
A fusion of ... ?
In lay terms, we mated sperm from the brothers with ova from the mother and sister to create new growth.
The CYLINDERS shudder as the voltage is increased.
And then we add mutating variables.
Anderson stares into the roiling vat.  Dr. Resfield waits for more questions.  But it is clear from Anderson's expression he has already learned enough.

Anderson sits in his office reviewing Precog discs for premurders in the local Washington area. We stay on him a watches the monitor.  He pops the disc, jots down some no slides in the next disc. Anderson's mouth slowly opens.  He leans close to the mon his face ashen.

Frank is on his hands and knees, working his vegetable ga He whistles softly under his breath as he trowels the ric soil. He sits up as he hears someone open the garden gate.  He lifts his straw hat in greeting, gives a smile.  It's ANDERSON.
What are you doing, playing hooky?
Anderson tries to smile.  But it won't come.  He looks ar the abundant garden.
It's great out here, Frank.. You got the touch.
Frank straightens with a grimace.
I got the arthritis, is what I got.

Anderson reflexively looks up at a high WHINING sound fro over head.  Frank follows his gaze.  A Precrime HOVERCRAF glides into position overhead. Frank stares, then lowers his eyes to the ground.  He tak a long sad breath.
Ah shit, neighbor. (beat) Goddamn Precogs don't miss a beat, do they? (beat) Can we do this inside?  Ellie's not home.
Anderson's voice is full of pain.
Sure, Frank.  Yeah.

Frank wanders the kitchen, trying to focus on his situati Anderson has trouble meeting his friend's eyes. Through a window we can see black suited police officers with mirrored helmets swarming outside Frank's house.

(distracted) I thought I'd buried it all. Thirty-five years -- all those minutes and days to bury it. (beat) But suddenly you see the man who murdered your daughter walking the streets -- my God it throws you.
Frank stops pacing.  He stares at a kitchen drawer.
He'd served his time, Frank.  I know it's not fair.  It's way beyond not fair ...
Frank looks.  At Anderson bitterly.
(yells) God damn the Precogs.  You know? Why couldn't they have been around to save my girl? (softly) Now they're catching me.
Frank reaches into the drawer and pulls out a small handg
I really shoot the bastard, huh? When?
Next Wednesday, at noon.
Good.
Anderson's cop eyes are all over the gun.
It's not in you, Frank, to kill anybody.
Tell it to the Precogs.  It's set in stone now, right?
Frank puts the gun on the kitchen counter.  Anderson rela
(almost inaudible) I don't want to be a part of this world anymore.
I know, Frank.
Frank gives Anderson a look -- no, friend, you  don't know . Then Frank looks hard at the gun on the counter.
(beat) So.  Tell me, Paul.  Do the Precogs see everything?
No.
Then they won't have seen this.
Frank suddenly snatches up the gun and presses it to his head.  On Anderson's anguished FACE, at the SOUND of the going off.

Anderson stands with his old partner, Witwer, on Frank's front porch.  Behind them, through an open door, we see L comforting Ellie D'Ignazio in the living room. Anderson is deeply shaken.  Witwer tries to talk him thro it.
(GENTLY) We
had to bring him in. Anderson doesn't respond.
He was a future murderer.
(angrily) You blame him?  The guy killed his daughter!
Witwer lets the implication of his words sink in.
Yeah.  I know.  I know.
Anderson turns and watches as they wheel Frank's draped b into the back of an ambulance.  Anderson's bitterness eru
I hate the Precogs, Ed. I believe in them absolutely and I hate them absolutely.  Jesus.
Witwer listens to him.
And that goddamn lab trying to grow more of them.  Put a Precog in every home, you know?  So we can have more Franks - people shooting themselves -- over who knows what?
Witwer kneads Anderson's shoulder, talks to him in soothi tones like you'd calm an agitated horse.
Precrime did the job it was supposed to do.
The two men can hear Ellie sobbing inside the house.
You know it.  And you believe in it.
Yeah.
It's not easy.  It beats us down. Ellie in there -- no doubt she hates you right now.
Anderson turns to Witwer.
That's why I got into this business -- to be hated.
Anderson almost manages a small smile.  Witwer puts his a around him.  Walks him away from the scene.
They hated us when we were regular cops.  Now we're Precrime, and they still hate US.  It's one of the little perks of law enforcement nobody knows about.
Their quiet laughter is tinged with sadness.  Anderson lo into his partner's good, open face.  Then they both look away, their understanding of each other complete.
Anderson stares out the window at Frank's house, illumina by the moon.  It's a mournful sight. Lisa rises on an elbow and watches him from the bed.

Ennis Page, in the mainframe room just off the Precog Cha picks up a black BRIEFCASE marked: "Zone 218 Washington / Alexandria, VA." He approaches the door, and his eyes are scanned.  The door opens with a HISS. We follow Page as he walks through doors and corridors un he reaches a long hallway leading to the Director's offic Anderson's secretary, Angela, looks up on Page's approach She nods.  He nods. He walks around her desk.  His eyes are scanned, and the door to Anderson's office opens. ANDERSON looks up, wearily.

Anderson inserts a disc into the video monitor, almost absently.  As we have seen him do before, he swivels his chair away from the monitor, and stares at Washington D.C across the Potomac.  Hovercrafts and transports skim thro the sky above the Washington Monument. The camera stays on Anderson's back as the sound from the Precog disc begins.  He hears his own voice speaking in strained, agitated tones.
Let's not do this, Ed.
Anderson slowly swivels around and stares with disbelief horror at the monitor.

shows Anderson and Witwer in a room, a few feet apart poi guns directly at each other.  Their eyes intense and pani Who murders whom? Ed's eyes cut to a huge digital clock on the wall as the seconds tumble away.
Oh, Ed ...

Witwer lowers his gun.  He stands unresisting before Anderson. Witwer sees his own death in Anderson's wild eyes, has al seen it. Anderson FIRES his weapon, puts a bullet straight into Witwer's heart, throwing him back against a wall.  Witwer slumps, dying, beneath the huge digital clock, which read 5:20 AM.

Anderson stares as the monitor fades to a blank.  His han goes to his mouth.  His body begins to shake.  He hugs himself, but he can't stop the shaking. The DISC pops out of the side of the monitor.  It is a sm SOUND, but it has Anderson up and out of his chair as if were a gunshot, He reaches for the disc but cannot touch His legs suddenly weaken, and he drops to one knee beside his desk, like a man in need of prayer. There is a single thought that screams through his brain. It is an almost visible thing, filling the room, blackly. Anderson whispers the sickening words that shape his fate
I kill you. (beat) Oh god, I
kill you. As Anderson pulls himself up, and tries to reach again fo the disc ...
In an image just like the scene in the beginning of the m the three FACES of the Precogs hover in the misty darknes Their closed eyes open in SUDDEN UNISON.  They speak as o
Murderer!
After a long moment, the eyes close again, and the Precog fade into the mists ...
Anderson looks up sharply at the SOUND of a knock on his door.  Every normal sound seems grotesquely AMPLIFIED, th traffic outside, his own breathing.
His senses are on overload. The door begins to open.  A stockinged leg is the first t Anderson sees.  His secretary, ANGELA.
Sir?

She hesitates before fully entering the room, Anderson gr at the incriminating disc.  He sees his EYES reflected in its alloy surface.  He pushes the disc deep into his pant pocket. Somehow he finds his voice.
Come in.  Angela.
She looks at him, uncertain.  Then she places a small sta of papers on his desk.
Need you to sign these.  And your eleven o'clock starts in five minutes.
My ... eleven.
(beat) Budget coordination with the FBI. (beat) You okay, sir?
Anderson runs his hand through his hair, can't think fast enough.  He sees her glance at the black Precog disc case He shuts it, awkwardly, and it auto-locks.
Have Page take this.
Angela steps back, disturbed.
But sir, the procedure
make procedure.  Call him. (long beat) I'm not okay, Angela ... you're right.
My head and stomach.  I'm going down to the clinic.  Or m just home. Angela looks relieved at the explanation.
Yes sir.
He moves past her.  His FINGERS fidget against the hidden disc in his pocket.
I'll speak to Witwer, put him in charge for the rest of the day.
He hesitates at the door, turns to look at his office, an at his view of Washington.  Then he is gone.
Anderson looks in the door Of Witwer's empty office.  He takes a step inside. Witwer's booming voice sounds from behind him, startling him.
Breaking and entering.  That'll get you five to ten, hard.
Witwer immediately scans his old partner's ashen face.
What's wrong?
Anderson can hardly bear to meet his friend's eyes.  He REACHES into his pocket, as if to lift the disc into the light.  If he could just do that, show it to Witwer.
Paul?
Anderson's hand comes out of his pocket, EMPTY.
Take over for me today?
You sick?
Yeah.
Witwer makes a show of backing away.
Don't give it to me.  You probably have that Trans-10 virus going around. A stomach thing.  I hate stomach things.
Anderson Almost smiles.
Ed.
Yeah?
Witwer looks at him.  Anderson almost reaches out for him
Run the place, okay?
(smiles) Sure.  Right into the ground. (beat) Go on home before I call Infectious Control and have them spray you down with something.
Anderson moves unsteadily down the hallway.  Witwer calls out.
You want me to do the discs, or hold them for you to review when you get back?
Can't let them back up.  Do 'em.
Call you later.  Take it easy, all right?
Witwer lifts his hand in farewell, Anderson fixes on that last image -- Witwer waving goodbye.
Anderson, sweating now, leans against a thick cement pill and pulls out a cell phone.  He hits a button.

head_text.subj: BETWEEN ANDERSON / LISA AT THE JUDICIAL CENTER

text: Lisa sits in a meeting.  Her phone CHIRPS softly.  She gl at the display, then rises to take it.  She goes to a cor of the room.
Paul?
Listen to me.
Lisa presses her phone close to her ear.
I can hardly hear you.
I'm underground.  Weakens the signal so it can't be picked up.
Alarm moves across her face.
But we're on Secure
Listen, dammit!  I'm going to murder Ed.
The Precogs picked it up. On Lisa -- can she have heard right?
Paul.  Paul His crackling voice faintly comes through the phone.
... home.
Lisa's phone goes dead.

Anderson looks down a long row of parked Precrime ground transports.  They are sleek and menacing, the black shell lumpy with dangerous gadgetry.  In the distance, a POLICE OFFICER, holding an armful of equipment, opens the back o one of them. He looks up at Anderson's approach.  He puts his equipmen down, and salutes.
Hello, sir.
Anderson nods, moves close.
What's your name, officer?
Bob, uh, Robert Smythe.
These the new Python transports?
The young officer turns and looks at the transport with p is about to speak, when Anderson touches a palm-sized Nov stun gun to the base of his neck.
(sincerely) Sorry, Officer Smythe.

The officer buckles.  Anderson catches him, rolls him gen into the back of the transport. Then Anderson quickly reaches into the transport, and beg stuffing equipment into a duffel bag: a helmet and black uniform, the weapon-glove, a folded rifle, a holographic scanner, and other equipment whose function we can only g at. Anderson looks up at a sound, echoey FOOTSTEPS.  They approach, then fade away. Anderson places the officer's hands and legs together, th aims a nozzled cylinder at them.  He shoots a spray of bl BindFoam chemical restraint, sticking the man to the floo of the transport in an adhesive glob. Then he leaves the scene, running.

Anderson grips the wheel of his Chevy, driving down 1-95. The fact that he can't control his car -- that the steeri wheel has no function, his speed is predetermined, and hi direction is guided by satellite -- is maddening now. From inside the cars that glide along beside him people t and look curiously at the man who is actually gripping hi steering wheel. Anderson slams it with his fist.  Through his windshield Anderson sees a four year old boy in the driver's seat of passing red and black Ford.  His mother sits in the passenger's seat, blithely reading.  The boy mimics Ander gleefully slams his steering wheel too, then laughs. Anderson turns and looks the other way, into the distance at the "Sprawl,' the vast unzoned city attached to Washin D.C. You can see it in his face: a man could lose himself there.
Anderson stands on an embankment.  He holds the Precog di in his hand, ready to throw it into the river. He stands like that ... and then slowly lets his hand dro He doesn't do it.
Lisa enters the house, in a rush.  Every shade is drawn. Paul Anderson sits in an overstuffed chair, absolutely motionless, like a man who has died suddenly.
Don't move.
Lisa doesn't get it.  She continues toward him.
Stop!  Moving heats you up, makes it easier for them to pick you up on their thermals.
She looks at him, scared, stops in her tracks.  She is suddenly suffocating.
It's a hundred degrees in here.
I turned the furnace all the way up. Your hair dryer.  The oven.  If they come, it'll buy me twenty seconds. Maybe thirty.
Nobody's coming for you.
Anderson stares at her.
On the phone -- what you said.  It's impossible.
She shakes her head in disbelief.  Anderson speaks, choki on the words.
I'm going to kill Ed Witwer.
It's

not true. Anderson's right hand hangs over the side of his armchair We see the bright DISC cupped in the palm.  He seems abou to reveal it to her, but doesn't, yet.  He keeps staring her intently.  Something is holding him back.
You're upset.  You've been unhappy. There's a lot of pressure on you. And then Frank ...
One week from today.  Tuesday, June 25, at five-twenty in the morning. I
shoot him, Lisa.
(beat) You need to take time off.
Anderson laughs harshly.
You don't have to worry about that.
She steps toward him.
(gently) I want to hold you.
If you love me, stand there.  And
don't move. Tears well in her eyes.
I saw the disc, Lisa.  I shoot him. In the chest.  And he dies.  I've watched a thousand murders.  This time I star in one.
Something's
wrong. You wouldn't do it.
The Precogs are
never wrong. They emit a single disc.  "The immutable evidence of the infallible system."
The room is terribly hot, his words -- she begins to sway unsteadily. Anderson focuses on her.  Her face.  Her hair ...
We'll figure this out.  We'll review the system.
There is no review.  There's only the disc.  It Shows My guilt.  There's no defense.
Her long hair.  He stares.
You can't run.  Please, let's --

A SOUND outside.  They both turn.  A deep silence.  The furnace churns out heat.  And Anderson looks at Lisa's ha ... and finally understands. Slowly, and very carefully, Anderson slides the DISC back into his pocket.  He rises from his chair.  For the first time he goes to her, reaches out, and touches her hair.
Last week.  It was strange.  I watched from the bathroom window.  You went out in the
backyard to make a call. She looks at him.
An appointment, you said.  For a haircut that afternoon.
Lisa's hand jumps to her hair.
You didn't get your hair cut.  You went to the trouble of calling first thing in the morning.  It was
that important ...
She reaches for him.  He pulls away.
Stop it!  Paul, please.  You're
panicking. Everything's going to look wrong.  You're going to distrust everybody and everything now.
Lisa implores him.
You
can't distrust me. (beat) It was Ed I called.
Anderson cocks his head.
Ed.  why outside?  Why lie about it?
Stop being a cop and listen to me!
A booming, electronically altered VOICE suddenly penetrat the walls of the house from outside.
Director Anderson!  There is no escape!
Anderson, betrayed, glares at his wife.  She's frantic.
Your birthday's tomorrow!  We wanted to...
But be's already on the move, running for the upstairs.
Drop to your hands and knees and stay there.  Precrime is entering your house!
Lisa screams, as her front door is sonically BLASTED off hinges, and a swarm of Precrime officers in mirrored helm hurtle in.
Paul!
They move past her and spread through the rooms and up th stairs like a disease in fast motion.
Helmeted officers hold their gloved right bands palm out, scanning rooms for thermal presence. An OFFICER 1 steps out of a small room.  He speaks, his v electronically altered.
He's got a hair dryer going.  Screwed up my reading.
The others nod.
We're not picking up shit.

They rush into rooms, with increased urgency.  We follow OFFICER 1 as he moves counter to the group and down the stairs. He hesitates as he moves through the living room, which i awash in personnel.  Lisa stands against the wall, pale a shaken.  He looks at her for a long beat, then steps over the shattered door and out into the sunlight.

Everywhere else in the neighborhood it is green and calm. But Anderson's house looks like a wasps's nest someone ha kicked.  Four Precrime hovercrafts are suspended above it engines WHINING.  Black Python transports are all over th street out in front, and more keep coming. And everywhere on foot, there are Precrime police.  OFFIC I approaches a Python ground transport.  Another officer guards it, weapon out, his head turning right to left.  H settles on OFFICER 1's approach and raises his weapon. OFFICER 1 doesn't even break stride.  He walks right up t the guard -- and then right  through him.  A holograph decoy. OFFICER 1 enters the Python.

OFFICER 1 removes his helmet -- it's Anderson.  And then comes the moment of truth -- have they cancelled his IdentiScan access to Precrime vehicles yet? A little scanner arm arches down from the visor, and flas a red beam into his eyes.  Anderson presses his lips toge The Python turns on, and a generated voice greets him.
Paul Anderson 0256 clear.

Anderson grips the steering wheel.  But his time, since i is a law enforcement.  Vehicle, the steering actually wor Anderson pulls out. FROM ABOVE, as the Python transport slips away from the c THEN HIGHER, and we see that the direction the Python is headed will take it from the green of the suburbs, throug the white of Washington, and into the dark of The Sprawl.

Ed Witwer sits alone in an antechamber.  He stares at an oversized oak door, then looks down at the floor. He runs both hands through his hair.  He is tired, his ey weary, lost. A voice comes over the intercom.
Enter now please, Assistant Director Witwer.
Witwer pulls himself together, and opens the door.

Witwer takes a seat at the end of a long table. Powerful men sit at the other end of the table.  SWANSON, sharp-boned, the FBI Director.  CRONIN, awl-like eyes, th CIA Director.  Senator Malcolm.  Chief Justice POLLARD, w face reveals nothing.  Vice-President ALMER, whose tongue darts across his dry lips unsettlingly.  Unpleasant looki men in an unpleasant mood. Cronin looks up from a printout he's been reading and sta at Witwer.
The central question is: Why does Anderson want to kill Witwer?
Cronin holds up the printout.
We checked your finances.
His finances.  Nothing irregular, you don't steal from him, he doesn't steal from you.  You haven't done anything that he might have discovered, and vice versa.
Swanson holds up another sheath of papers.
Personnel checks reveal no ambitious coups planned by you to topple him. (beat) He's done nothing to you, or you to him.
Witwer presses his lips together.
You fucking his wife?
No.
HIS MOTHER?  HIS BROTHER?
Witwer gives him a bad look.
Okay.  There we are.
So, you are friends, partners, and soul mates.  Anderson has no motive.
I can't think of one. (beat) Maybe JUSTICE POLLARD The Precogs are mistaken?
Witwer looks away.  Jesus, he wants out of this room.
You don't believe that, do you?
(barely audible) No.  The Precogs are infallible.
Senator Malcolm is impatient with all this.
You're goddam right.  So, gentlemen -screw the motive.  We got a pre-murderer on the run, and a nasty little PR problem.
The very powerful men level their unpleasant gazes on Wit
And here is our solution.  You are now
Director Witwer. Witwer shakes his head, starts to protest.  Almer silence him with a raised finger.
Precrime must demonstrate its willingness to go after one of its own.  Total impartiality.
Now
look
Cronin talks right over him.
The public must believe that every future murderer is pursued with equal vigor.
Therefore, Precrime will put in charge the man best suited to the job.  And who would pursue a murderer harder ... than his intended victim?
You went after Anderson yesterday -because it was right, and because you
believe. Almer speaks with a tight irony.
And your belief will certainly grow stronger with each tick of the clock.
Witwer looks at the men with thinly-veiled hatred.  But h does not deny their words.
Haw long will it take, Director?
Wiltwer takes a long breath, concentrates his mind on the task he can't avoid.
He knows Precrime, of course.  And the streets -- he's rusty, but he'll remember how to work them.  It'll come back to him fast.  He's ... the best.
Witwer almost smiles.  Justice Pollard's not smiling.
We're not here to praise Caesar -- we're here to bury him.
Witwer looks at Pollard, then lifts a finger and touches right eye.
He can't avoid iris identification. Every door he opens, every ATM he uses, or taxi or transport he boards -- he'll get scanned. (quietly) It won't take long to find him.
The eyes that look back at Witwer are unblinking.

The unzoned city is full of 1950's iconography, but it al feels different than it did in the suburbs.  Where the bu were Ike, the city is Joseph McCarthy. The fat Ramblers and Studebakers have a little grime on t The women's dresses are tighter and more urgent, the men' suits have some shine at the elbows.  You look over your shoulder here, move faster, and smile a lot less. And some streets you don't go on at all.  Anderson's Pyth moves down one of them.  He stops under a blackened suspe bridge, gets out.  He's still in uniform.  He holds a duf bag. He starts to walk away from the Python, then hesitates. He's left the door open.  He shakes his head at his sloppiness.  Goes back and shuts the door.  Walks away ag
He's left a small DEVICE on the passenger's seat.  Digita numbers shoot by in reverse.  Something CLICKS.
Anderson continues walking away.  He doesn't look back as the Python is engulfed in a miniature sun of heat and fla It's not a gasoline powered vehicle -- so it doesn't expl It just ceases to exist.
Through a smeared window Anderson sees racks of suits and dresses hanging in clear plastic bags.  He gets to work o the door.
Lisa lies in her bed, alone in the dark.  She listens to almost inaudible sound, a high WHINE.
A Precrime HOVERCRAFT floats high above her house, a dark moon in the low clouds.
A worker stands in the back of the store puzzling over th clean clothes piled on the floor.  It almost looks like a nest, like someone slept there

Anderson, in a blue suit and fedora, carrying his duffel bag, stands on a subway platform.  He takes out a cell ph dials a number.  He looks up at the SOUND of a train. The approaching MagLev train has a lit sign on its front car: "33rd Street Express."

Search and Command room.  Witwer moves up and down the ai past technicians who man computers and holographic tracki displays. A Precrime TECHNICIAN 1 suddenly sits upright.  Witwer pi him out of the crowd and zeroes in.
It's Anderson.
Witwer grabs a phone, punches a button
Paul!
The technicians scramble to pinpoint Anderson on a Glowing holographic MAP.
Anderson, holding his phone, is IdentiScanned along with everyone else as he steps onto the train.
Another TECHNICIAN 2 calls out to Witwer.  Witwer covers phone mouthpiece.
He's been Scanned.  He's on the 33rd Street Subway!
TECHNICIAN 1 Calls from the other side of the room
His cell phone tracks for The Sprawl. We got him on the Subway, too!
Anderson sits on a seat in the rear of the car.
Why am I going to kill you,Ed?
There's no motive
My wife calling you before breakfast?
We were planning a surprise party. It was going to be today. (beat, ironic) Happy birthday, partner.
This party's no fun, Ed. It's a hell of a surprise, though. (beat) I'm having trouble trusting people, Ed, I gotta tell you.

At Precrime, they upload a MAP DISPLAY of the Express tra route.  We see a blue light moving -- the train.  And two separate red dots along its route. An OFFICER points at the dots, and speaks to Witwer in a voice.
The train makes two stops, here and here: 20th, then 33rd Street.
Witwer covers the Mouthpiece
(to the officer) Split the units, go to both
We'll never make 20th
Witwer waves him away -- do your job.   Now.
You there, Ed?
I'm here.  You gotta come in, Paul .
I'm a Cop, Ed. I need a motive.
Come in.  We'll figure this thing out together.
Precrime transports zoom through the city
Anderson looks out the window into the tunnel dark.  He t to Witwer.
It'll get ugly if you keep running. And your eyes, Paul -- every move you make a Scanner will pinpoint you for us.
I saw a news flash.  You're the new Director.  Is
that the point of this?
Fuck you.
Anderson smiles.
Didn't think so.  But it has to be
something, Ed. Witwer looks at the DISPLAY MAP.  We see the blue train nearing its first stop, 20th street.  We see two waves of lighted green dots -- Precrime units heading for 20th and 33rd.
Paul.  Come in.
Anderson sees an overhead light come on in the train: "Ne Stop 20th Street.

If I come in, it puts me close to you.  If I get close ... I may kill you.  I can't risk that. (beat) Anyway, they'd force you to lock me up.  And that'd be it -- I'd never get my chance to solve this thing.
Witwer needs to keep him talking
You're kinds liking this, in a way, aren't you?  The action ...
And you get to be a real cop again. We get to flex our muscles.
Precrime vehicles pull up.  Hovercrafts appear in the sky above.
Anderson's train is just finishing off-loading passengers The doors close and the train begins to pull out as the f helmeted Precrime officers flood the platform. One of them points.
Anderson is visible through the window, talking on his ce phone.

Witwer stares at the map.  The train has stopped at 20th street.  But Anderson's  still talking.  He isn't getting off -- he's going on to 33rd Street, the last stop. Technician 2 presses his earphone close, listens, then ca over to Witwer.  Witwer covers his mouthpiece.
We have visual verification -- he's still on the train.
Witwer gives him a thumb's up.  We STAY ON Witwer as he listens to Anderson, and watches his train move toward 33 on the MAP.
I want to tell you something, partner. You listening?
Witwer nods.  Now the MAP shows all the Precrime units swarming toward the 33rd Street subway station.
Yeah.
I gotta do this.  I have to figure this thing out. (beat) But listen to me now.  If it was
you running, I'd come after you, Ed.
Witwer stares at the MAP, at all the units he's sent afte his friend.
You're a cop.  And I'm a future murderer. (beat) Do your job, Ed. Come after me
hard . Because, Jesus Christ, I wouldn't sleep or eat until I had tracked you down and put a gun to your head.
Precrime officers pour down the stairs toward the train platform.
Witwer watches on the MAP at all the little symbols mergi together, like a gameboard -- but this game ends in a rea confrontation between one man and an army of them.
You wouldn't shoot a cop would you, Paul? (beat) Paul?  Paul?
He looks urgently to the phone technician
He's still on the line.
Witwer presses his ear to the phone.  He can hear the sub make its STOP.  Then he hears a chorus of mechanized VOIC -the voices of the Precrime police, the SCREAMS of panick passengers
Police.  Everyone down on your hands and knees! (then) Oh, shit.

The Precrime officers aim the index barrels of their gloveweapons at ANDERSON, who sits blithely on a seat, ho his cell phone to his ear. Anderson begins to shimmer, then dematerialize ghost-like into nothingness.  He was a holographic decoy. What is actually there on the train seat is Anderson's ce phone.  Rigged to its mouthpiece is a tiny digital voice recorder.
Anderson trots up the stairs and safely out onto the stre of The Sprawl.

Every city has its underbelly.  If you lifted the fat dar underbelly of The Sprawl this is where you'd end up. The streets here feel like alleys, clotted and tight.  Th are streetlights, bright ones -- but the light dies at it source, never makes it through the sour air down to the ground. The retro fifties look comes apart here.  The people that you see -- and you only catch quick glimpses of them, the move like rats -- wear black mostly, tight fitting tech-fibers. ANDERSON'S caught one of the rats, a thin bald guy in bla Anderson has him pinned up against a wall.  They're havin some kind of exchange -- which consists of the guy answer none of Anderson's questions, and Anderson pressing him h against the wall. Finally, the guy does something odd.  He lifts a finger a pulls down Anderson's right lower eyelid.  Anderson lets him.  Then the guy does the same on the left.  Has a long look.  And then nods.  Anderson releases him, and they go off together.
An oppressive brick thing on a side street.  The facade i crumbling.  Nothing good happens in a building like this. The guy leads Anderson to the building, then scurries off into the night.
