He starts to get off, is actually on the platform, then steps back onto the train. The rushing dark again.  When the MagLev eases to a halt the next station he gets off this time.
He walks toward the exit stairs with a handful of people. He eases back and lets them go up first.

Precrime officers crouch around the bend, silently snatch people out of the way as they come into view.  They wait -but Anderson does not come.  And he does not come. On signal, the Precrime officers rush down the stairs.
ANDERSON hangs high above the doorway near the ceiling, adhered by one arm there by a blue glob of adhesive BindF

as they run below him down the stairs.  They go out of si he can hear them rushing along the platform searching for him. The strain of hanging by one arm is killing him.  He reac up.  With a laser knife, and cuts away at his coat sleeve releasing himself from the glob.  He drops to the stairs, and instantly slips up them. He surprises a helmeted OFFICER, just around the bend.  H slams HIM against the wall, yanks off his helmet, and hol the laser knife against his throat. The OFFICER 1s clearly terrified.  He speaks hoarsely thr Anderson's choking grip.
Don't kill me!  Jesus.  Please.
Anderson looks at the panicked officer.  Anderson closes eyes trying to put it together.  He opens them.
But the Precogs would've predicted me killing you.  You'd
know whether I do or not.
The officer looks at him with eyes begging for mercy. Anderson suddenly gets it.  He tightens his grip on the m
They shut down the system.  Haven't they?  They've
shut down the Precogs. The officer nods.
They're off homicides.  They're redirecting them to help us locate you.
Which is how they knew where he'd be every time. Anderson chops quickly at the base of the man's skull, knocking him out.  And then he runs, because what else ca he do?

Lisa stands in a long hallway outside a door, labeled: COURTROOM 17.  She holds a briefcase in one hand.  Down t hall, other courtrooms are in use, but not this one.  She enters the dark and vacant Courtroom 17.
Lisa sits at the judge's bench in the empty courtroom.  T lights are dim. She takes a small, battery-powered tv out of her briefcas She turns it on.
The murder of Witwer by Anderson is being shown over and over in a continuous loop.  Flashing at the bottom is the hotline number: "1-800-PRECRIME." Then- "Call Now!  Call Now!

Now Lisa takes out the Precog disc Anderson gave to her - first disc. She places it in the specialized monitor on the judge's b The tv and the judge's monitor sit side by side.  The tv plays the version of the murder from the second disc; the judge's monitor plays the version from the first disc. She stares intently, her eyes flicking back and forth fro one version to the other.  They seem absolutely identical When the judge's monitor goes blank, she starts it over a Lisa stares, watching her husband murder his best friend, endlessly.
A gas station right out of the fifties.  An attendant in uniform and cap whistles while he wipes down the windshie of a sky blue Rambler. In the background, Anderson walks toward a men's room.

Anderson looks at himself in the mirror.  He reaches out touches one reflected eye, which is a deep brown.  It is still startling to him, the color of his eyes. Then he reaches into his duffel bag and takes out the air syringe Doc gave to him.  He looks at it nervously.  It i filled with 5 cc's of an opaque green liquid. He touches the tip of it to the soft center under his chi He closes his eyes.  Then he screws up his courage, and h the plunger.  The liquid is pneumatically delivered with searing HISS. Anderson  screams out in agony, slams back against the wall of the bathroom.  His hands reach up for his face -- whic looks like it's boiling from within.

The skin on both cheeks begins to pucker.  The muscle ton around his chin goes soft, and begins to sag like an old man's.  That is the effect -- like he is aging fifty year His forehead wrinkles, the skin under his eyes droop.  He pink is replaced by bloodless gray.

head_text.subj: AND MOTHER OF GOD DOES IT HURT

text: The ATTENDANT knocks nervously on the door
You all right in there?

When the door opens, an unhealthy looking old guy with a fedora hat pulled low comes slowly out of the bathroom. Anderson nods, and walks past the attendant, who watches after him uncertainly as he wanders off.

The perky tour guide we met earlier takes another group a the headquarters.  There may be a massive campaign to fin Anderson, but the Precrime public relations machine conti to run without interruption. There are ten people in the group, and the physically transformed Anderson is among them.  They all wear glowin nametags.  Anderson's reads, "Mr. Symington." He keeps hi hands in his pockets, and his head low. We have heard the tour guide's spiel before
Welcome to the main headquarters of Precrime.  Smaller Precrime branches are scattered throughout the United States.
She is about to go on when she looks over at Anderson.  H is fidgeting uncomfortably.
Are you ... all right, Mr. Symington?

Anderson moves up close to her, a little too close.  He whispers to her, embarrassed.  She gives him a profession smile, and points in the distance past the elevators. Anderson nods, and heads off.  She calls after him.
We'll wait right here for you, sir!
Anderson runs down a back stairwell to a lower floor.
Anderson stands outside a door marked: "Housekeeping." Ab the doorway is an IdentiScan device. Anderson reaches into his coat and carefully removes a sm cryo-jar.
Imbedded in the clear gelatinous coolant are two eyeballs -the irises a luminous blue.

The operations room in Precrime.  The technicians sit at their computers and holographic tracking displays. Witwer paces among them.  His eyes keep flicking to the digital clock on the wall.  Then they cut back to the men and machines that are telling him nothing.  Witwer does n look well at all, When a TECHNICIAN leans close to his computer monitor,Witwer almost leaps across the room to g to him.  He looks over the man's shoulder.
What is it?
Must be a glitch ...
What?
Anderson just got IdentiScanned.
Witwer grips the back of the technician's chair.  The technician types the data through again.
It's him -- he's been scanned.
Where is he?
The technician looks up at Witwer.
But he's had his eyes done.  Right? Sir?  Tries to think it through.
(barely audible) He had to have.
The technician's computer flashes the next piece of information.  When he speaks, it's the last thing Witwer wants to hear.
Jesus Christ, sir.  He's in the basement of this building.
All eyes turn to Witwer.  The unspoken question hangs in air.  Anderson's come to murder Witwer?
Throughout the building, every available Precrime Officer begins to receive orders to mobilize toward the basement.

Four officers stand guard in the chamber.  They listen to the orders coming in on their earpieces.  Three of the gu rush out of the room, one stays behind. The three Precogs sit in their oversized chairs, the fema in the middle, the males on either side of her.  Their ey are open ... and they are deeply alert. Two technicians tend to the Precogs.  At the back of the chamber, through a large window, we see Ennis Page sittin at the huge mainframe.
A ring of Precrime officers three men deep stand guard ar Witwer.  Witwer looks like he wants to kill them all.
This is
ridiculous. Lieutenant Glaser replies forcefully
Standing orders from the Security Panel, sir.
If he wants to get to me, he'll get to me.
No, he won't, sir.
Witwer looks at the confident young officer almost pityin Then his eyes flick to the wall clock.
Armed Precrime officers clog the corridors, conducting defensive searches of one room after another.  All they a coming up with so far are some very startled housekeepers
In the chamber are one guard, two technicians, and three Precogs.  And all of them are left in sudden darkness, as the power is cut.
The officers around Witwer reach for their maglite flashlights.  The Search and Command room suddenly looks exceedingly vulnerable. A technician calls out from the darkness
Don't worry, air -emergency generators will kick on in five seconds.
The green glow from a roomful of wristwatches makes the r seem alive with fireflies.  Five seconds go by.  Then ten more.
Explanation, please!
Uh, sir.  It seems ... he got the generators, too.
There is a long moment of silence.  And then Witwer begin to laugh.
The room is utterly dark and silent.  The silence is brok by the SOUND of something rolling across the floor.  Some speaks, probably the guard.
Shit.

An explosion of light fills the room in STROBE-LIKE blast And leaping through the light is ANDERSON.  The temporari blinded guard and technicians have dropped to their knees Anderson stun guns them quickly. The strobes fade, and Anderson sets a zirc-flare on the f We see that the enzyme is wearing off -- his facial featu are returning to normal. He is oblivious to the Precogs in their chairs.  It is th equipment he is after. Through the observation window we see ENNIS PAGE watching horror as Anderson severs the light cables connecting the Precog helmets to the mainframe. Anderson aims a sonic blast at the observation window, bl it out and knocking Page unconscious.  Then he reaches in the room and destroys the mainframe itself with a series blasts. Anderson is so intent on destruction he does not sense a PRESENCE behind him.  Perhaps it is because the movement so completely devoid of malice it is beyond detection. A HAND, the fingers pale and slender, reaches out and tak hold of his hand. Anderson whirls around, weapon out.  And there before him is the FEMALE Precog.  He looks at her, then beyond her t the other Precogs who are lolling in semiconsciousness in their chairs. Her helmet is off.  She is young, but her close-cropped h is silver white.  And when she speaks, her voice is like wind whispering through time.
Save us, Anderson.
Anderson can feel the seconds ticking away, his carefully planned operation interrupted in an unfathomable way.
I have to get out of here.
She grips his hand.
Save us.
It is beyond pitiful, this frail little woman, pleading. And her eyes, she won't let him go.  She is beginning to weaken, to sway on her feet. A sudden realization floods over Anderson.
You
let me get here, didn't you? You stopped giving them information, so they couldn't track me.
The Precog female is fading fast.  She tries to reach out for him and her legs give way.
Save --
And what can Anderson do but catch her before she falls? What can he do but throw her over his shoulder, and in th fading light of the flare, make a run for freedom.
Lisa has been staring at the judge's monitor and the tv s for over an hour.  The two versions of Anderson murdering Witwer play over and over.
(wearily, to herself) Help me, Paul.

She hits freeze-frame on the judge's monitor, at a moment during his confrontation with Witwer when Anderson's FACE fills the screen. Lisa looks with deep urgency into her husband's eyes. And it is his EYES, finally, that tell her everything.  L hand rises to her open mouth.
They're blue.

She keeps the image on freeze-frame, and turns and looks the tv, which shows Precrime's disc over and over, the 1- number scrolling along the bottom. When the same close-up of Anderson flashes onto the tv sc she leans close to it and squints. Anderson stares right back at her.  And for the first tim Lisa sees that the tapes are not exactly identical.  His eyes...
And now they're
brown. For the first time in days she allows herself a small smi

Power has been restored to Precrime Headquarters.  Witwer walks slowly through the ruins of the Chamber.  EMT teams work on Ennis Page and the other dazed personnel Anderson has left in his wake. Technicians cluster around the two remaining Precogs, the brothers.  Their eyes are closed and they are limp.  Thei lips move soundlessly as if in conversation with each oth Lieutenant Glaser is with him, but when Witwer speaks it almost to himself.
Why didn't the Precogs know he was coming to do this?
The Lieutenant has no reply.  Witwer runs both hands thro his hair.  It has begun to wear him down, the ticking of clock ...
The next time he shows up it'll be to kill me.
We won't let that happen, sir.
Witwer takes in the chaotic scene around him, then gives Lieutenant a withering look.
You won't, huh?
When the Lieutenant tries to speak to him, Witwer walks a and goes over to the technicians working on the Precogs. stares at the Precogs.
(to a technician) When can we get these things operational?
They're a hive mind, sir.  It takes three for their predictive abilities to be fully operational.
Which Witwer does not want to hear.  Witwer leans very cl to the technician.

These two are all I have to find the man who is about to murder me.  Hook them up, and flood them with whatever kind of fucking chemicals you have to.  They are a machine, and I need that machine at my disposal.
The Precogs's lips stop for a microsecond, and then begin their silent movements again.

Ennis Page is a man unglued.  He sits on a tidy little so in a tidy 1950's style living room.  But his movements ha become untidy.  He puts a very tiny pill on his tongue. When he drinks from a glass of water, it dribbles down hi chin onto his shirt.  Not like Ennis, at all. When his doorbell RINGS, he slowly looks up, then looks d at the floor again.  He doesn't answer it.  It RINGS some more. And then Lisa is standing there before him
Your IdentiScan is off, Ennis.  I could just walk in here.
I forgot.  To turn it on.
She sits down beside him.
You don't look surprised to see me.
She glances at the bubble pack of pills on the table besi him, three gone.
I need your help.
Unexpectedly, tears well up in Ennis's eyes.
He took one of my babies.
He's desperate, Ennis.  He had to. (beat) We have to help him.
Lisa holds the Precog disc in front of his eyes.  He clos them against the sight, as if it were an evil talisman.
It's a
fake Ennis. Ennis's eyes open again.
This is the first disc.  You delivered it to Director Anderson.  He reviewed it.  And then he stole it, and went on the run.
Ennis tries to think through his fear and haze.  His word slur.
I delivered ... a fake .. to him?
But he thought it was real, and ran with it.
The pills, his tidy world coming apart -- Ennis is losing it.
An hour later, you delivered a second disc of the same event.  Witwer reviewed it.  It was real.  (Beat) How do I know this?
Ennis just wants her to go away.  He wants it all to go a Tears stream down his face.
Director Anderson had his eyes changed.  They were blue.
Now he has
brown ones. Ennis is sliding away.  Lisa takes hold of him.  Makes hi listen, dammit.  She points to the disc in her hand.
This disc, the fake one, shows a blueeyed Anderson murdering Witwer two days from now.  He doesn't have blue eyes anymore.  The person who faked this disc had no idea he would change his eyes.
Lisa shakes him.
Listen!  But the
second disc has to be real, because he has brown eyes when he murders Witwer.
(beat) Somebody tried to frame him with a fake.  And somehow it all became
real . Why, Ennis?  How could this happen?
Ennis gives her a look that's on the other side of comprehension.
You handle the discs.  How did a fake one get delivered?
Ennis's eyes roll back into his head. PAGE Coffee ...
You want-- ?
He spilled coffee everywhere ... Everywhere ...
What coffee?  What are you -- ?

But Ennis sags unconscious.  She shakes him hard, even sl him, but Ennis is out.  She lets him drop down on the sof From outside the house, somewhere high in the clouds, com the WHINE of a hovercraft. Lisa looks once more at Ennis, then gets out of there

A small, dreary room, invisible with insignificance.  Whi is just the kind of room you want if you've stolen a Prec The female Precog lies on a cot.  Anderson sits on a meta folding chair watching her. Her eyes slowly open and look at him
My brothers aren't here.
You didn't even look around.  You knew.
(beat) We can sense each other.  You must save
Anderson cuts her off with a curt shake of his head
Stop.  I saved
You. It was the best I could do.
She turns away and looks at the yellowing paper on the wa There is a fading pink cabbage rose.  She traces the outl of it with her thin finger. She turns back to him.
Thank you, Anderson.
It is deeply eerie for him, chatting with a Precog.
What am I going to do with you?
Her eyes grow very serious.
Name me, Anderson.
What?
Give me a name.  I've never had one.
Anderson rises, moves around the small room.  He is shame embarrassed.
Listen.
She turns to the wall.
Listen to me. (beat) Listen to me ... Rose.
It is heartrendingly touching, the smile she gives him wh she faces him again.
Rose.
Rose.  They shifted your precognition so you would locate me.
(beat) Yes.  And it hurt us, physically. Did you know that?  The helmets, the controls.  It
hurts.
(guiltily) I didn't know.
For a long moment he can't say anything.  But there are t he needs to understand ...
When they shifted you to find me, you didn't reveal everything.  That I was going to break into Precrime.
We saw our chance.  You would need to shut us down, you would have to come.  We wanted you to come.
You used me -- to save you.
have been used all my life, Anderson.
Anderson can't meet her eyes.
No one cared that we were human. From a human mother.  Taken at birth. Hooked to machines. (beat) We have been alive, Anderson. Enslaved, for the greater good.
Her words are unbearable, for both of them.  She traces t outline of the wallpaper rose again.
But now I have a name.  And I know the man who has named - me will not allow me to be enslaved again.
Anderson looks at her, then goes to the window, carefully watches the street below.
Rose.  What's going to happen to us? Can you see that?
I'm weak.  And away from my brothers. I see glimpses and hints of things nearby.  But it's all ... scattered. (beat) I'm tired of the future, Anderson.
She lies on the bed, watching as Anderson comes back to h He sits carefully on the side of her bed.
Then be reaches out, and gently touches her cheek
You didn't know I was going to do that, did you?
She is almost too overwhelmed to speak
No.  Oh, Anderson.  It was lovely.
And now it is Anderson who is overwhelmed

If he were not already dead, it would've killed Ennis Pag to see the state of his living room.  Precrime officers everywhere.  Blood on the rug.  A gun beside the sofa. Witwer stands in the corner of the room witching the Coro crab walk Page's body.  It WHIRS and CLICKS as it probes takes samples from various sites. The holographic doctor waits patiently as the Coroner cra makes its determinations. Lieutenant Glaser talks quietly to Witwer
Who else could it've been?
The crab probes the ragged hole in Page's head
He grabbed a Precog so he could commit an undetected murder.
(beat) Page worshipped the system.  He fell apart.  Shot himself.
The Lieutenant rolls his eyes.
Anderson.

Witwer doesn't say anything.  He just stares at the body crab finishes.  The holographic doctor unfolds his arms a turns his head to Witwer.  He is only a computer interfac but even so, it seems as if there is surprise in his digitalized voice.
Director Witwer.  This event is a positive homicide.

(beat) A mortal wound was generated by a .38 calibre bullet delivered to the left occipital portion of the anterior skull, on June 16th, 2040, at 1:24 am, Eastern Standard Time.  A Phase Two Investigation is in order.

No one says anything as the holographic doctor dematerial and the Coroner crab walks across the floor and puts itse back in its box. At last, someone moves.  It is Witwer.  He lifts his arm, pulls back his shirtsleeve, and stares long and hard at h watch.
Lisa sits biting her lip as Witwer watches two monitors p the two versions of Anderson's murder of Witwer.  Lisa po
There.
She reaches down and freezes on a close-up of Anderson on the two monitors.
On the left monitor Anderson has blue eyes, on the right has brown.
The one on the left, the first disc -it's a
fake. He doesn't have blue eyes anymore.
Witwer stares for a long time.
A fake.
But the Precogs predict the infallible truth.  They don't emit fake discs.
And now Lisa smiles.  She has set her lawyerly mind to th solution.  It is her moment .
Exactly. You can't tamper with the Precogs, induce them to make fakes
(beat) But that doesn't mean someone couldn't have made a fake disc on their own and inserted it into the delivery system.
The simplicity of it is inconceivable.  Witwer speaks carefully, trying to process it
Bypass the Precogs and slip a fake disc in with that day's real ones...
(excited) We're all programmed to believe anything we see on a Precog disc. The system has never been wrong ...
Witwer stares at the proof before him.  -- the different colored eyes of Anderson.  He ejects both discs and holds them in his hands.
You have to call off the hunt.  He was set up.
Witwer looks at the two discs he is holding
(long beat) It's gone too far, Lisa She shakes her head, shocked at his response
He was set up!  You
both were.  If Paul kills you, you're both out of the picture.
Who wants us out?  Of  what picture?
Jesus, Ed. Stop this thing!  And then we can investigate Witwer's mouth opens and closes.  He tries again.
Ennis Page was murdered last night.
The blood drains from Lisa's face
Everything points to Paul.
He's
not a murderer.
I think he is.  A murderer ... and a future murderer. (beat) Lisa.  What does it matter that the first disc is a fake ... if the second one's real?
Witwer's hands close tight on the discs.  Lisa stands the motionless.  Then she turns, and leaves his office, abrup He watches her go.

Rose sits in a chair near the window.  She is chewing lig on a cracker.  Her face shows wonder -- at the cracker's texture and taste.  She holds it up and admires its shape Anderson's mood is less wondrous
Rose.  Listen to me.  I'm going to leave you here.  I have to keep moving.
No.  You must save my brothers.
It's impossible.  There's no time. I've done what I can do!
Rose waits for him to finish.  She looks out the window a the street scene.
Come here, Anderson.
He does, reluctantly.
Do you see that boy in the blue hat walking with his mother? (beat) In sixty seconds he will walk beneath those workers installing a window on the tenth floor of that building.
Two men struggle to lift a large window in place.  Way be the little boy in the blue hat walks on along the sidewal holding his mother's hand.
They'll drop the window, killing him.  It is impossible to save him.

Anderson turns to her, shocked And then he runs for the d hurls it open, and disappears down the hall. Rose listens to his FOOTSTEPS crashing down the stairs EXT. THE STREET. Even as Anderson rushes out of the boarding house, the WO have lost their grip on the window. The little BOY in the blue hat and his MOTHER walk unwitt toward disaster.  They do not appear to hear the MEN'S cr The WINDOW falls end over end above the boy's head.  The sunlight sparks off of the glass, so that from a distance looks like a star falling from the sky. A WOMAN across the street sees what is happening, and cri out. But what Anderson does is  run. He runs faster and harder than humanly possible.  He does not care if he is recogni or hit by a passing taxi.  He is going to get to that boy He  has to get to that boy ... ANDERSON rams the BOY from behind just as the corner of t window frame kisses the boy's blue hat.  He knocks the bo to safety as glass and metal SMASH into the sidewalk. The mother does not even have time to scream.  She is on ground, stunned, But Anderson has saved the boy. He rolls away, and gets to his feet.  Before anyone can p together what has happened, Anderson has ducked into an a and is gone.

Anderson enters the room again, out of breath, some small cuts on his face and hands.  He stands across the room st at Rose. Rose considers him.  When she speaks her voice is near an distant at the same time.  For Anderson, it is as if the words are coming from a place inside his own head.
It was impossible to save that boy -- but you
did, Anderson.  It's in you.  It's what you
are . Anderson sits on the floor and leans back wearily against wall.
You
knew it wasn't impossible.  That I'd get there.
Rose reveals nothing.
You are a man who saves others. (beat) Save my brothers.
Anderson almost laughs.  Her persistence is unbelievable
I'm in a lot of trouble right now.
My brothers are in more trouble. They've moved them to ... an awful place.
Rose.  Ed Witwer -he's in the most trouble of all.  Who saves
him

Rose suddenly grimaces in pain, and grips the side of her head.  She curls into a fetal position. Anderson goes to her, touches her thin shoulder.  Her eye roll into the back of her head. Whose pain is she feeling?  Her own?  Someone else's? Anderson doesn't want to think about it.

Because Anderson has destroyed the Precog Chamber, the tw Precog brothers have been brought here. The room is makeshift, uncomfortable ... a place for experiments.  The brothers are strapped into chairs.  The are helmeted. But unlike before, large bore needles have been placed in their jugular veins.  Connected to the needles are long t of IV tubing.  There are several IVs running at high drip rates. Witwer has his back to all this.  He stands with Dr. Resf watching a technician working the keyboard on a huge mainframe. Dr. Resfield, a man not given to squeamishness looks back the Precogs, uneasy.
We're not really set up for this type of
He stops talking when he looks into Witwer's hollow eyes. is somewhere beyond the influence and reach of words.
Anderson tries to get Rose to drink some water.  Her skin translucent, unhealthy, glistening with sweat.
Rose.  Try to drink.
She pushes the cup away.  She closes her eyes, as if even the dim light of the room causes her pain.
Your wife.  We have to get her here, Anderson.
She opens her eyes.  Anderson doesn't like the feel of th
Why?
I don't know ...
What are you seeing?
Glimpses, Anderson.  Please.  We have to get her here.
You're scaring me, Rose
She covers his mouth with her hand
Stop talking.  It uses me up.
For a long time, Rose says nothing, Her gaze is locked on a distance beyond the room.  At last, she speaks.
In three minutes your wife will take a walk ..
Lisa sits in her office.  But she can't stand it, the sit and waiting.  She has to move.
She gets up and hurriedly leaves her office
Witwer walks past Lisa's SECRETARY toward the open door o Lisa's office.
Sir?  I'm sorry, she stepped out for a few minutes. (beat) Sir?
Witwer stares into the empty office.  There is a clock on Lisa's desk.  His eyes fix on it.

Lisa moves quickly down the steps of the white marble building.  She takes a deep breath, then heads down Jeffe Boulevard toward the city. A sleek black TRANSPORT with two Precrime officers in it follows her from a discreet distance. In the sky above, the ubiquitous Precrime hovercraft

Lisa walks down the street.  She hugs herself, barely awa of her surroundings.  She passes by stores, restaurants, payphones, video kiosks ... oblivious.  People push past her. On a street corner, as she waits at a red light, the payp beside her begins to RING.  If she hears it, she gives no indication.  A KID reaches for it, listens, hangs up. She walks on.  Stores.  Restaurants.  An art gallery.  As she comes abreast of another PAYPHONE, it suddenly starts ring.  This time Lisa glances at it.  But again, walks on The TRANSPORT weaves through traffic, nearby She walks pa the K.L. Lawrence Graphics Museum.  And another restauran And a PAYPHONE.  And this time, finally, when it, too, RI she turns and looks hard at it. A man begins to walk over to it.  Lisa almost knocks him of the way to get to it.  She grabs at the receiver.
Hello?  Hello?
I need you.
Lisa's forehead sags against the side of the payphone.  S basks in the sound of him.
It's 1:03.  Set your watch, exactly.
Lisa pushes the buttons on her digital watch as she liste LISA Okay.
This is what you have to do ...
We now hear ANDERSON continue in VOICE OVER as we follow Lisa through a SEQUENCE OF EVENTS ...
Lisa walks up the steps of the museum
At 1:07 hang up the phone and enter the Lawrence Museum.
Lisa walks quickly through a display of 19th century maga advertising.
The two Precrime officers walk into a room filled with Ch graphics.
At 1:13 the two Precrime officers following you take a wrong turn into a different room, losing sight of you for ten seconds.
The officers start toward the entrance way to another roo then hesitate uncertainly, and go for another entrance wa
Lisa hurries down the steps
Lisa boards the "A" MagLev train
An undercover transport officer will have received emergency orders to follow you. (MORE) He's wearing a red tie.  He has short blond hair.
The blond transport officer with the red tie sits at the end of Lisa's car, watching her. At the next stop Lisa gets off.  He follows, not too far behind.
Lisa starts up the stairs.  She looks at her watch, then makes herself pause a few moments, to keep within Anderso time frame.  She starts up again.
As you come around the bend, cry out and turn around and slap the officer...

Lisa does this, and the officer reels back, surprised. At same moment two big men rushing to catch a subway come in view, and see this happening.  Lisa starts to run.  When undercover officer tries to stop her, the two men grab th officer, and they get into a fight. Lisa escapes.
Lisa looks at her watch, then taps the window for the dri to stop.  She gets out.
Stay on Ninth street.  Underneath Ninth street is the main power feed for The Sprawl.  It'll mess up the navigational beacon on the hovercraft. (beat) Keep switching taxis.  But stay on Ninth.
She hails another taxi.  She holds her hand over the IdentiScan before it can read her.  The taxi driver looks her, sees her smile, sees the prepaid cash card she holds out to him.
Two hundred dollars if you don't scan me.
It's The Sprawl -- stranger things have happened.  He gra the card, and jerks his head for her to get in.  They tak off.

Lisa gets out of the taxi and looks briefly into the sky. It is dense with holographic billboards, skim-jets, dirigibles.  Somewhere in all that is a Precrime hovercra And the neighborhood around her is definitely downscale.
The hovercraft will try to drop altitude, but the air traffic will slow it down. (beat) Precrime loses you.  You'll have to walk two miles.  Don't get scanned.
